item.title: Re: T2000 Server: It's our Continuous Integration and Staging server!
item.description:
>There's something I've been meaning to ask: As I >understand >it, our software will be hosted on SFSU's T2000 server and >it will run live from there to its prospective users.
You're right here... As an Staging Server, it will be running the different versions as I explained below for the following users: customers, professors and the development team.
>Since >this is an open source project, however, does it mean that >anyone can download a copy our software from Java.net as >well?
I think we can assume 2 things when working with open-source projects: we all use free open-source components to build our own solution. That means, I use Open-source frameworks as my building blocks. And here's where the difference is: you can give final users the software as a download, or you don't. For what I have in mind, we WILL NOT give final users our final version of the software, BUT they will be able to download the source code from the subversion repository. We can make things difficult for users to build our software if we desire to NOT give them the software for free...
> If so, will that be maintained in parallel with >Subversion on the T2000, or how exactly will that work? >
This is explained in the bottom of the page... When Gary and the other IT guy explained about it, they said students were going to use FTP to transfer files over... Are you kidding me? Staging servers use Subversion to checkout from the same repository, where we have control on the revision we want to checkout... In this way, the continuous integration system takes care of ALL the automation of creating directories, moving artifacts around, MIGRATE MySQL DUMPS to the database version (YES, Databases ARE VERSIONED and I will explain later why) making the necessary configuration... There's nothing else it does other than to grab the versions of our RUNNING software. This is an Agile way to do things, where we see where we are in the development... Read the topics below as I explained the different versions of the software that will be provided...
What you can use this server for is as a Free MySQL server for you... I don't think this is a good thing to do, since you can work in your own computer (way faster).
Let me know if you have any more "unanswered" questions... READ topics 1 and 2 from the original post for details!!!!
Marcello

item.title: Communication challenges: how to make the team work!
item.description:
hi team!
From my experience with open-source software development, I think we are not getting engaged in the project as we need to be... Local groups are in HUGE advantage because they are getting together locally at the campus, and doing their jobs from home... However, we have a much more interesting group set up and this will be the case in our future careers.
Distributed teams usually work using Intranet IMs (Motorola uses a version from MS Messenger, Collabnet, Google, Sun, Apache use private/public IRC channels on freenode and private IRC servers). That's not because of the big ones, but because we need to maintain our contact alive and because the professors will just want to participate on online conversations and we still haven't get together in our own setup... So, for this reason, I would require everyone to be logged in to the IRC channel PPM-8 at Freenode.net... whenever you are online in your private time we all could chat and actually have the daily conversation about the project, milestone documentation, etc... Whenever possible, we would use DimDim.com for presentations with our desktop if needed... Just complete steps 1 through 7 at
http://www.wikihow.com/Register-a-User-Name-on-Freenode...
I added my IRC client application today to the Startup, so you could do the same to not forget about it... Our team channel/chat room is called ppm-8. Once logged in to the IRC, just type /join #ppm-8...
Marcello

item.title: T2000 Server: It's our Continuous Integration and Staging server!
item.description:
Hello InfinityTEAM!
Finally Gary and Prof. Petkovic presented the T2000 server. It will be each team's staging and continuous integration server... Everyone got the information for the server, but unfortunately our team got the wrong password set up... I tried loggin in and I couldn't... I have already sent an email to Gary to solve the issue... So, they have a space for group8 to host their executable, running software... In any open-source, distributed software development there are 2 ideas for verifying the current development:
1. Staging Version of the Software: this is the final release of our software in a given version. Let's say:
a) Version 0.1 containing the complete system running, with the version of the Database schema, etc; b) Version 0.2 running, containing everything that evolved from 0.1 and the features added/planned for 0.2.
So, Staging is usually offered to the client as a way to show it up and running. When the software is released to stage, it is usually in the end of an iteration, and it is said "to be ready for QA". That means that the TESTING team will use the software to see if it passes Requirement tests, defined in the documentation. This team usually works "AGAINST" the development team in a way to try to BREAK anything... :)
2. Continuous Integration (CI) refers to how agile products are automatically integrated and built. Using Subversion, the continuous integration server does SVN UPDATE every day whenever a new commit (a new revision) has been submitted by the developers. Also, it has the Nightly builds links so developers/users of the application can get it from there... In this way, the CI server maintains a freshcopy of the most updated software from the subversion repository up and running... If the build is broken, the software for CI will display the ERROR message, THE DEVELOPER's NAME who did broke the build, etc. In this way, all the team members will get the idea that the module/package/class/function he/she has written was correct and has not affected the current software. For this reason, it is highly recommended that before committing any code, you could do PAIR PROGRAMMING PEER REVIEW, a practice where developers exchange DIFFS of their current work and ask them to verify their work locally.
I will be setting up Phing http://phing.info/trac/. It is similar to Apache ANT and will generate things for us automatically...
http://phpimpact.wordpress.com/2007/06/30/phing-php-project-build-system-based-on-apache-ant/ http://www.slideshare.net/arnoschn/continuous-integration-and-php
This is the page of the CI software: http://code.google.com/p/xinc/
NOBODY will be NEEDED to learn about this... Just see the result of your build whenever it is ready! It will email everyone with the status :D However, if you are interested to know more about it let me know...
We will be able to CREATE additional databases for our personal use, and use PHPMyAdmin. For development purposes, I would suggest to stick with your own local server in your machine, and if desired create a new username and password online... Here is the basic information about that:
Server: hci.cs.sfsu.edu
* Main FINAL INFINITYNET to be staged in December: - http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/~group8
* Nightly Build: - http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/~group8/builds/ general information, lists all the builds available, links to download the versions...
- http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/~group8/builds/current It has the most current build as for the current date... It can be broken, or not
- http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/~group8/builds/verified It has the most current build that WAS VERIFIED BY QA (tested, etc). I will cover more on automated tests later;
- http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/~group8/builds/nightly/yyyymmdd/ build for the nightly build version of previous dates
Continuous Integration Build: http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/~group8/builds/
MySQL to create users http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/mysql
PHPMyADmin http://hci.cs.sfsu.edu/phpmyadmin
I also thought about creating a Subdomain name for the project, instead of using the regular SFSU address... This could be an optional stuff... http://www.knows.it/
Thanks, Marcello

item.title: Re: Gmail
item.description:
Thanks Andres for the tip!!! Just to notice that this configuration is already set when using Firefox!!! This configuration setting seems to be for Internet Explorer, right??? In any case, that's a good one...
SSL tunneling encrypts everything you are transferring from your browser to the server and anyone "listening" on the port 80 would grab that information (pure clear HTTP/HTML code flowing). However, SSL tunnels are on port 443 and everything is encrypted! Just for another point of interest, this uses the RSA encryption algorithm, which is basically based on Public Key encryption. Your computer always creates these keys for you while navigating in browsers with https connections (which are tunneled through port 80).
Have a good one everybody!
Marcello

I've worked in teams that just don't use FORUMs because of better email systems with search. So, anything would be based on the topics you write, how you expose your ideas, etc. You can also do search on Forums, but sometimes it's just the process of receiving an email, and having to click on the link, make the usual login, in order to finish the process of reply. That takes way 5 minutes from you :) Count those 5 minutes over a period of a month, or maybe this semester and see what you would get from that... :D This is the extreme line of thoughts... :)
I think we should go with either one... However, as I'm noticing in the project is that since I don't see that many replies on Emails, it's easier to have the web forum to monitor ourselves... We are going to be evaluated by our participation as a team...
So, the best way in the end is to play by the rules of the game... (which I have already found a mid-term to write documentation...)

item.title: Gmail
item.description:
This is somewhat unrelated, but since we're all using Gmail for the project, it concerns us all & I thought I should share what I heard on a podcast the other day. It turns out that Gmail by default doesn't use SSL to transfer information between the browser and the server, so it's pretty much a visible connection (not secure). This can be easily remedied by going into Settings -> General tab -> Browser connection (last option) and select 'Always use https'.
Voila!

item.title: Addressing the "e-paper trail" from Gary's email about Group Communication
item.description:
Gary explained in his email today (https://ppm.dev.java.net/servlets/ReadMsg?list=users&msgNo=19) about the e-paper trail we have to leave in this project... How are we going to address this?
So, by nature, we are an open-source, distributed and collaborative development team and that's what happens in real world projects... All the communication is done through the online tools offered by the project hosting server and we are also remembered that this project will go on after we finish our cycle, but we need to leave our footprints and our history on the project. Everything today is indexed by Google and this is a good opportunity for our future careers. In this way, I want to remind you guys about our communication challenge:
1. Always use the General Forum to discuss about something we still have open. Something that will be in the history of the group such as the project name, regular team meetings dates, decisions on the architecture to be used, frameworks, etc. But, it's important to have everyone participating on the decisions together; If you need to have a topic to be decided, just open a new one and all the team is going to be happy to reply.
2. The mailing lists are there for a purpose, when it comes to Open-source software development: they are the main channel of asynchronous communication for us and for our clients. They should be used according to its specification. Let's keep using them for daily activities, problems we have to address, fixes of problems created, etc.
I started using the dev mailing list to discuss about everything, and I realized 2 days ago that it was being over used. We will balance accordingly this time... Any comments?
Marcello
